description:

title: 20-Minute Power Tool Storage
description:
💚 A huge thank you to The Brotherhood: https://www.patreon.com/brothersmake
♻️ Check out our recycled plastic store: https://www.brothersmake.com/shop

title: 33. Ditch pegboard for shadowboxing #mtbitesize #shorts #makethings
description: One of the biggest and costliest tool storage regrets I have is surrounding my garage walls with pegboard.  If you’re just starting out, my advice is to stay far away from this pressed paper: it’s ugly, weak, expensive, frustratingly cumbersome and I, myself, regret ever using it.  Because it has to be anchored away from the wall, you’ll have to trim each section, which takes away hook placement.  If it’s not anchored to the wall right, you’ll get dips as the pegboard will collapse under stress.

video_title: How to hang an IKEA pegboard without screws, using Command Strips
text:
i'm posting this 6 months after putting up my peg board. i added an additional bar to the back and attached them vertically so i could put more command strips on them. i think attaching the strips horizontally or cutting them into smaller pieces reduces the load capacity of the strips. 

my peg board is still hanging securely on my wall. it's definitely important to be mindful about how much weight you're adding to the peg board. i use the shelf attachments, which adds a lot of weight by themselves. i only put small plushies and gacha figures on mine. screws may be a stronger/permanent alternative, but this method suits my current needs and situation.

video_title: Organize Garage - Hang Tools for Cheap
text:
+Mikel Kd - "quick fix"  -- That's pretty misleading as it would only take about 4 minutes more to have put up a sheet of Pegboard, particularly on a wall with wooden studs as opposed to a concrete block garage wall.  Simply nail up some 1x2" furring strips onto the studs, then use some 3/4" screws to attach the pegboard to the strips.

$19 for a sheet of pegboard is just too cheap and easy an alternative to use instead.  You end up with:

a. More flexible uses: you can quickly move the pegs anywhere as tools change or are added over 32 square feet of storage on just a single sheet
b. Better use of the wall space: 2x4s waste a ton of wall space by definition if you hang anything other than these full length tools, that's why he only shows them being hung.  So now you can also put all the small but regularly used tools at quick reach, like hammers or even screwdrivers with an inexpensive or even homemade mount for them.
c. Something that adds resale value to the home instead of looking like it was built by the Beverly Hillbillies.

A single sheet of pegboard would add 5 times the useful storage that this design provides, and for no real effort or time more, and barely much cost difference for a homeowner.

text: I want to give a good shout out to slatwall. I have been using slatwall in my shop for years. I have shelves, pegs, hooks for specific items, it works perfectly. It's not for everyone tho, I have definitely come to the conclusion that what is the perfect solution for one person is definitely not even applicable for another person. A great example of this is bike storage. For some people, those hoist systems are perfect. For others hooks are perfect. For me, neither are good or optimal or even an option. I also have 7 bikes to hang in a very small space. But again, for someone else, it could not be more perfect

video_title: 6 Awesome Shop Storage Systems to Organize Your Workshop (or Garage)
text:
The rolling tool chests have evolved and work very efficiently, for a few key reasons: 1) the drawers are a good size to visually scan, and depth fits a great majority of standard tools. Liners and some internal organizing is all one needs to learn what goes where without over-organizing and wasting space; 2) more small cabinets can fit on top, and drawers are at or below eye level, a real problem for built-in shelving and cabinets over work areas. 3) Most drawers fully extend, and are very strong even loaded with tools. 4) You can move them nearer, or away, from areas, and unlike tray systems, aren't likely to tip over. The metal construction is rigid, but thinner than any wood drawer systems, which are heavy and usually built semi-permanently, demanding a lot of pre-planning design.
  If your shop is for miscellaneous repair and DIY work, not woodworking, building out a full storage and wall system is impractical and costly, without all the wood tools needed.
author: @z1522

video_title: 6 Awesome Shop Storage Systems to Organize Your Workshop (or Garage)
text: Slatwall, like Gladiator GearWall. You’re using the wrong product (tracks). Use the Gladiator slatwall with Premier tool cabinets. The Gladiator steel hangers are stronger, hold more weight than French cleats. Plywood cleats tool holders often must be bigger than the tools. You can fit far more tools on a Gladiator GearWall with hook hangers and this system is infinitely adaptable for ANY storage needs. We installed the slatwall on all three garage ❤

Really balanced presentation!  One thing I would add is that the "rail" that I have is a 1x3, painted white, with either dowels, hooks, or nails in it.  That's what I have in my garage, all the long things hang from that.

You make a good point about being locked into a brand with some systems.  In my opinion, no one should buy into any system that is brand specific, if for no reason other than it will eventually be cancelled.  Use plywood, cabinets, cleats, pegboard, open shelving.  If there aren't many companies making the product, you're both stuck and paying too much.

video_title: 6 Awesome Shop Storage Systems to Organize Your Workshop (or Garage)
text: "Enjoy" your video? No. I found it incredibly depressing. If these are my only realistic options, I'll NEVER get my workshop organized. I've already got my tool density almost a full order of magnitude more dense than yours and still can't seem to efficiently organize: a 19" bandsaw, 2 bench-grinders, a miter saw, a 7"x21" lathe with associated rests, chucks, & vices, a combo disc & belt sander, vacuum cleaner, dust collector,  ultrasonic cleaner, 15 gallon air compressor, an assortment of handheld power tools (Sawzall (2), impact driver (2), cordless drill (2), dremel, heat guns (2), angle grinder (2), portable belt sanders (2)), a collection of clamps, bench vice, a drill press, a full set of hand tools (wrenches (SAE & Metric), sockets (SAE & Metric), ratchets, power bars, torque wrenches, screwdrivers, numerous hammers, allen wrenches, saws, various cutting tools, pliers, tin snips, bolt cutters, riveters, staplers, hot glue guns), propane torches, precision measuring tools (calipers, micrometers, runout gauges + support hardware, levels, squares), taps (SAE & Metric), dies (SAE & Metric), punches, chisels, soldering irons, multimeters, along with all the replaceable cutting/sanding (sandpaper, steel wool, blades, cutting wheels, grinding discs, bandsaw blades, sanding belts & discs, drill bits, razor blades, lathe cutting tools, mill ends, vacuum filters, etc.) consumables. PLUS various raw materials (wood, metal, plastic, wire, rope, screen, nuts, bolts, nails, specialty fasteners, rivets, staples) used to create things. Also, all the lubricants, glues, solvents, & cleaning solutions to support projects. My workspace is 10' by 20'. Two ends can't be used because one is a garage door, & the other is a walkway. Oh, I forgot airless painter, paint, drywall related patch stuff. I'm not including my numerous shovels, picks, pruners, leaf blowers, edgers, hedge trimmers, chainsaws, machetes, rakes, brooms, string trimmers, loppers, sledge hammers, etc., which I have organized into a 1.5'x1.5'x8' space. None of those systems you showed seemingly could accommodate my collection of tools & materials, leaving me depressed. Your demonstration of a broom & shovel wall hanging solution made me laugh. I have over 5X the number of tools in that category you showed I've got it packed into that 1.5'x1.5' space I mentioned. I want to get everything neatly organized. I fix stuff, & I make stuff. I also do my own gardening. I tend to work more with metal than wood, but I have the tools for both. Oh, I also forgot what I call my specialty tools: borescope, lasers, label printers, magnifying glasses, temperature measurement tools, and on and on. Oh, I also have a portapower with dies. When I was a little kid my father told me "A man has to be able to fix anything." I took that to heart. He might have just been joking. Dunno. I was just a kid. I sure as heck can fix way more than he ever could.

video_title: DIY Garage Storage / Shelf / Workbench Solution
text:
The top two shelves should have been configured like the work bench 4/8/4 rather than 8/8.   it makes no sense to have two cantilevers meet in  the middle rather than a solid span above the bench with two 4' wide towers on each side. 
Bins can be stacked.  The top shelf is not necessary.  And it's omission would allow the header above the bench to be raised  5" to avoid head bumps.   
A bench height of 38' to 44" is more ergonomic for standing work and provides space for two roomy shelves under the bench.
Using wall studs for support is efficient provided fasteners shear strength exceeds loads.  Rec 4 1/2" lag screws.

video_title: Four Workbench Building Mistakes (that we all make).
text:
I’m actually happy with my workbench. Super sturdy, massive enough, good enough. It was my first bench and serves me well. 

One mistake i see people make is to drill 100 perfectly aligned holes for holdfasts to anticipate every unknown. When you going to need them? Propably never. A way that comes from machine work world.

I really like a simple shash clamp and a piece of plank when holding a larger or weird piece of woods. The situation is always different and I don’t have to engineer a holding solution to anticipate it all. Just adapt fast and continue with the project straight away.

video_title: Four Workbench Building Mistakes (that we all make).
text:
I very much don't align with the "pinky knuckle" advice for bench height. Maybe there's more to consider with torso/arm lengths because if I followed that advice it would have me leaning over an uncomfortable amount even if I were planing 8/4 stock. I can feel my lats engaging just from getting into position to plane at that height. 

I'm not saying it's not great advice for most, but if you are oddly proportioned like me (I'm like 25.5" pant inseam, 6'1") you might want to really consider starting higher. 

I started at 40", but 38" is where I landed. I'm considering going another 0.5" lower, but giving it more time before committing.

video_title: Four Workbench Building Mistakes (that we all make).

The weakest methods either got replaced or went out of business,  so what the old fart traditionalists know is the combined knowledge of thousands  of craftsmen over as many years... Including those you don't see in your blind spot. That goes for exceptionally smart people as well. So while our society has advanced thousandfold or more in some areas, other are so simple, yet so complex and interconnected, bound by physics and nature, that in 99.9% of cases, you'll end up straight back with what you tried to run away from or avoid. Because it works. And out of all the millions of alternatives,  that one won. For good reason.

video_title: Four Workbench Building Mistakes (that we all make).
text:
if you can set your work on it and it makes it at the right height... and is fairly stable...  its a good bench... my main bench has six legs not four... 4'x10' six legs, two layers of plywood, and a sheet of replaceable MDF on top, its the same height as my table saw so it makes a great outfeed table, no clamps or vises on it, they just get in the way, if i need to clamp something ive got toms of various kinds of clamps i can clamp whatever im working on to the table if i want... built in vises made from wood are gimmicky and never work that well, i much prefect just using clamps... i have real ,metal vises on my welding table that actually works well... but even still i never use it for woodworking... i just use clamps way easier and i already have a bunch of them.... bench dogs suck, built in vises suck, "woodworking benches" suck... just give me a nice solid  flat tabletop i can clamp stuff to... leave out all the gimmicky shit...

bigger is better... you dont have to set shit in the middle... but if you got something big youll be glad you have the space... also good when youre making lots of stuff or stuff with lots of parts that need to all be laid out... the only time bigger isnt better is if you have a tiny cramped shop... then yeah you gotta fit the space, otherwise bigger is better. i have five benches that are 4x10 or bigger, and i still always wish i had more bench space...

if youre more interested in building furniture for your youtube video, then yea whatever... but for actual woodworking... i never use that shit... nor do i want to... its the old slow way... we have modern technology now... dont get me wrong... im all for sticking with what works... but not when it takes longer or is more work and no better result... then im gonna do it the easy way...

video_title: Four Workbench Building Mistakes (that we all make).
text:
Your first statement was me. I bought my first home and said, "I have a house, I need a workbench!" Long story short, my top rested on the four corners and not the supports running between the corners, or the middle support I added. When I figured that out, I had to use some plastic shims and now at least the supports are offering support to the top. 😅

I just learned my "supports" are actually called "stretchers". :D

AND... I used carriage bolts and nuts and I've had to tighten mine too!!!!! 😄  Where were you 4 years ago when I bought my house? Oh, this video was already made, I just didn't know about it. hah  Mine is similar to the half lap joint you're describing. Except I used 2x6s instead of what looks like 4x4s and the stretcher is completely supported by two bolts through the 4x4 leg post. It kind of looks like the image at 18:30, only mine has a bunch of shims. 

This is a fun video!!

video_title: Four Workbench Building Mistakes (that we all make).
text: My first basic workbench was a sheet of 72x36 plywood sitting on a couple 2x4s across 2 saw horses. Not good, except for assembling, painting, and finishing. My first big bench (in my garage) was a sturdy 2x4 frame with a 3/4 plywood surface screwed on. It sat on 2 Keter workhorse folding workstations. 8 legs made the work bench stable in every direction, it could hold 700 pounds, and it could be folded up and stored easily. The top hangs on the wall of the garage.  When the plywood top gets banged up, flip it over and you have a new surface. When that side gets banged up, it's time for a new sheet. (inexpensive) I have a clamp-on vise that works very well, and can be removed in seconds.

video_title: Four Workbench Building Mistakes (that we all make).
text: Mr Krueger, I have watched about a dozen of your videos but that promise to ‘not let those problems happen to you” finally won my clicking suscribe. There were three questions I had in regards to my bench that I wanted answered before I finish my plans and started building, the first was leg joinery I have been debating between a half lap and a laminated mortise and tenon (where the beam for the mortise is made from three laminated 2x4s) I am going with the mortise and tenon option. Second was on bench “length” as you call it (my learning is mostly from drafting so I would call it width and what you called width I’d call depth). Third question was about cross braces as in whether or not I needed them. thanks to your video I have decided the answer is yes at lest for the front and back, currently the bench is 14” deep with a plan to make it 20” in a few months (once I figure out if I am a good shop manager that puts tools away or a chaos gremlin that needs a tool trough.) Most of my past work bench experience is from shop class and carving. You also answered a question I didn’t even know I had which was in regards to a vice. However you are making me second guess my height. I’m 5’6, in the past for carving I have worked at 35” and for all the other stuff I’ve worked at kitchen counter height which I hated I was thinking 34-35” for the bench. I think I am still going to start there after all my dad has a circular saw that can take care of the finer tuning, in a perfect world I’d have the money and skill to build a height changing one. But hey that can be a goal.

video_title: How To Build A Workbench - The Best Way
text:
So I am planning on using this design to build the same bench but having it be 6'x12' my thoughts are I will need to do a 3rd row of legs to support the center. If you have any ideas on this let me know. I am planning on giving it a try over the next few evenings after work. I will update as to how it goes.

Update. AMAZING WORKBENCH! I did go with different dimensions and I am beyond happy with how it turned out since moving to a new house we have so much garage space it only made sense to make a large table since we end up spending half of our time on the floor building large projects so this will eliminate that! I completed this project in only 5 hours. I only did 6 legs just like in the video, I have yet to add the deck boards for lower storage due to the fact I could only fit so much wood in the jeep. Dimensions I went with:
Table top: 5.5'x12'
Table height 38"

Lumber Used:
Ten 2x6x12' (for the table top)
Three 4x4x12' (legs cut to 36" and support beams going between legs on the lower half cut to 54")
Eight 2x4x12' (support for the table to to rest on and going the long way between the legs I also added one more going between the legs the long way down the middle)
Two 1x2x12' (for support where the deck boards will rest on)

I still need to go and buy the deck boards for the lower support but what I will need is:
twenty four 1-1/4x6x6'

Only difference is my top is 3 2x10 osha planks that I attached w dowels before screwing down & my bottom is 1x3 slats for a box spring that my neighbor threw out. wish I could include a pic
author: @briandimascio3624

video_title: How To Build A Workbench - The Best Way
text:
Thank you for this video. We moved a few years ago and all my tools were just thrown into the garage. Now that it's warm enough to work outside, I've been trying to organize the garage and set up my tools again. I knew I needed a proper workbench, and since I haven't spent much time building things, I was hoping to find something simple. THIS build checked all the boxes. I made mine 10' long and a few inches taller. It worked out perfectly. Lumber in our small town is way overpriced so I only had to buy some 4x4 and 1 10' 2x4 because I only had 3 @16'. I had some salvaged tongue and groove boards that I used instead of the deck boards. I couldn't believe it when they fit almost perfectly after cutting off the tongue edge for each side of the table. I didn't have to rip any boards. Also my hardware store didn't have 5/16 lag screws at 5" long so I had to use 3/8. They were a little harder to tighten with my impact (even after predrilling the holes), but everything worked out great. Building this table has really improved my confidence and drastically increased my motivation to get back to work. 

Thank you very much!
author: @jlcouto85

text: I am not a mechanical engineer. However, I feel many people commenting may be missing the fact that the uni strut is suspended over multiple truss. This IMO should spread out the weight across the various trusses. .... But I am not positive on this. Let me know if this sounds correct: If you are lifting 1,000 pounds then the weight across 5 trusses should be 200 pounds each???  I am going to try this in my shed. But I did modify my truss with a rafter going across first (extending over the top of the wall plates, hope this is sufficient. I am only planning on lifting maybe 400-600 pounds.  The other thing is there are the clamps around the uni strut, which should help prevent the uni strut channel from spreading.

text:
Regarding the hoist vs winch.  Some are designed for double duty.  For example my has a vertical and horizontal load rating.  It can lift and pull.  

Also be sure you are not attaching to a truss system specifically the bottom chord.  Those have low ratings typically little above the drywall and other ceiling fixtures.  I'd call county inspectors or a structural engineer before hanging any lifting system.  The call is free.  Auto body repair and ER visits are not.

text: Easy way to align the two sets of wheel assemblies is to mount both sets of wheels on the motor housing but don't tighten the 4 bolts.  Then take two C-Clamps, two pieces of straight wood scrap sticks, then clamp the wood sticks (one on each side of the wheels, with the two C-Clamps.  Next tighten down the 4 bolts holding the wheel assembly to the motor housing.  POOF - Wheels assemblies are aligned with each other and rolls freely.
